_comment: Created by ianb on 04/03/2014 10:16:33 using v2.1
title: How has the proportion of women having adequate cervical screening changed by age?
analysis_commentary:
We have seen that overall cervical screening coverage for women aged 25 to 64 increased in 2008 but has been declining since 2010.

Current good practice is for women aged 25 to 49 to be screened every 3.5 years, while those aged 50 to 64 should be screened at least every 5 years. When we separate these age groups there is a difference in the trends over time. The overall increase in coverage in 2008 is only seen in women aged 25 to 49. The proportion of women aged 50 to 64 adequately screened has actually been decreasing since 2005, most noticeably from 2009.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, breast screening programme and cervical screening programme
